Posts.Content: Hi there Maria! For pain caused by my bone mets I take Oxycontin which is time released and long-acting. I take Oxycodone for breakthrough pain. The Oxycontin doesn't make me drowsy or anything, I just take it three times a day and I'm ok. Pain caused by cancer is unlike any other pain I've had in my life! I was a Division I athlete in college and had 4 operations on my ankle, but it never hurt as bad as my bone mets do. Unless you've experienced it, there's no way to know what it's like. Vicodin and Percocet didn't cut it for me, but the Oxycontin does the job. Cancer pain is way out of the realm of Aleve and other OTCs.
Posts.Title: best "pain meds"?

Posts.Content: Hi klayr, I had 5 nodes removed when I had my mastectomy last summer. Like you, I had reconstruction. I did experience shooting pains in my armpit and phantom itching, but I have not experience pain as you describe it. It never hurts to get a second opinion, but I remember my surgeon telling me that I might experience pain for up to 2 years as well. Should you worry? I don't think worrying solves anything, but you do owe it to yourself to get it checked out. The peace of mind you'll gain will be well worth the time spent on an office visit!
Posts.Title: mastectomy survivors only please

Posts.Content: Hi floridalady, If you decide that you want to pursue the test, investigate clinical trials and other research programs. That's how I got my test. If you get into a trial (which you probably will b/c of your mother's diagnosis) the test is free. You can look for clinical trials on *****.com.
Posts.Title: Braca 1 & 2 genetic marker test for breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi there Jillian, I'm a 27 yr old breast cancer survivor, diagnosed at 25. In my opinion, have the lumpectomy because a mass can be composed of several types of cells: invasive cancer, carcinoma in situ, and even benign tissue. If you opt for a core needle biopsy, what happens if the surgeon samples a part that is benign and you go home thinking there is no problem. When my tumors were biopsied they were composed of all three types of cells I listed above. I'm so glad that I had the lumpectomy b/c my surgeon was better able to treat me knowing what he was really dealing with. I hope your biopsies come back negative! I know it's scary, but remember, even if it does turn out to be cancer it doesn't mean you're getting a death sentence! I'm fine now, and so are millions of other women. I'll be thinking of you!
Posts.Title: What are the odds in your opinion?

Posts.Content: Hi snoopy, I found a lump in my breast when I was 25 (I'm 27 now). My first ultrasound detected that lump, and another one. The ultrasound showed they were both solid and had to be biopsied. When I had my second ultrasound, the smaller lump was not detected. Ater my biopsy I learned I had Stage II breast cancer and the smaller lump (the one that didn't show on the second ultrasound) was deadlier than the larger one! It's not great that your lump has grown, but that doesn't mean you have cancer. There are many things that lump could be and unfortunately cancer is one of the possibilities. I'm not trying to scare you, just trying to encourage you to take care of yourself. Get another ultrasound at a different hospital and compare the results. It's so important to ask the right questions and insist on getting answers. If one Dr sends you home saying "You're too young to have breast cancer" find another Dr that will listen to what you have to say, read your ultrasound and spend time on the diagnosis. It's really scary not knowing -- you'll get through it! Please make sure you get more tests done! -Kalie
Posts.Title: Ultrasound and lump

Posts.Content: Hi analee, I'm a 26yo breast cancer survivor. Go to a Dr and get it checked out. If the lump hasn't grown or changed shape in years, chances are it's nothing. Malignant tumors grow and change. You will not necessarily have to have a biopsy. The first thing a Dr should do is order an ultrasound. The ultrasound can tell if the lump is fluid filled, meaning it's a cyst, or if it's a solid mass. If the ultrasound shows that it's a solid mass, the Dr may order a biopsy. I cannot stress enough how important it is to just get it checked -- it could save your life. Most likely, you'll find out that the lump is nothing to worry about and you'll feel so much better because you won't be afraid anymore!
Posts.Title: lump in my breast

Posts.Content: You should have the lump checked by a Dr. Are your implants saline? Saline doesn't form lumps when it leaks b/c it's basically water. The lump is also not likely to be scar tissue forming against the wall of the implant because your implants are under the muscle -- you wouldn't be able to feel a lump under your pectoralis, and your lump is over your pectoralis. The lump could be a cyst, a fibrous benign mass, or a cancerous tumor. I don't mean to frighten you, but as a breast cancer survivor who found a lump I urge you to get it checked out.
Posts.Title: Breast lump and implants

Posts.Content: Don't beat yourself up about not going to the Dr, nellie! Just make sure you take care of yourself from here on out. Thanks for asking about my health. My cancer was caught at stage II (2 tumors in the left breast, no metastasis or lymph node involvement) which is early and very treatable. That was 2 yrs ago. Unfortunately, I've had a nasty recurrence and it has spread to my lung, liver and back. I just learned that a few wks ago. I am now stage IV and undergoing chemo, but I should be fine in a few months. The medical community is having a difficult time with breast cancer in women in the their 20s b/c the cancer behaves differently and has different characteristics from cancers in post-menopausal women. I was diagnosed at 25, I'm 27 now. I think the important thing that people should know about cancer is that it isn't a death sentence. I have to go through some pretty harsh treatments, but I'm going to be fine. Take care of yourself and post back when you learn more about your lump. I'll be thinking of you!
Posts.Title: Breast lump and implants

Posts.Content: Hi there! I'm sorry to hear about your mom -- I hope she is doing well after her surgery. Life gets much easier once the Drs remove the drains. I'm a 26yo breast cancer survivor (stage II, e/p horomone receptor positive, aggressive). I was tested for both BRCA1 and 2, and my results were inconclusive. Researchers know that mutations in these genes may lead to breast cancer, but not all the mutations are mapped. Some mutations are deleterious (meaning they may lead to breast cancer), other mutations are not deleterious (meaning no potential problems), and some (lucky me), well they're just not sure what these mutations mean. Testing positive for mutations in BRCA1 or 2 does NOT mean you will develop breast cancer! What it does mean, (to me anyway) is that you have an opportunity to monitor yourself more closely and adjust your lifestyle to help prevent breast cancer (maintain a healthy weight, only drink 1 alchohol drink per day, exercise regularly, possibly take a drug like Tamoxifen to prevent the breast cancer from ever developing. Besides, only 10% of women diagnosed with breast cancer have a family history of the disease. My family has no cancer history at all, and I lost a breast to cancer at 26. I know how you feel right now, it's really nervwracking. The important thing to remember is that no matter how the results turn out, women today have a fabulous chance of beating cancer and preventing recurrences. There isn't a day that goes by that the thought of a recurrence doesn't cross my mind, but if I let myself obsess over it, I'll gain nothing, and lose the great days that I have. Good luck! I hope you test negative! Hang in there, Kalie (hug) [This message has been edited by Kalie (edited 10-24-2003).]
Posts.Title: Braca 1 & 2 genetic marker test for breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, 2 yrs ago I had Stage II breast cancer and underwent a mastectomy with reconstruction. I did not have chemo b/c my lymph nodes were negative. Well, hello again old friend! I learned this week that my cancer is back and this time it is Stage IV as it has spread to my right lung (not the side of the original cancer), my liver, and the small of my back. My Drs are very positive about my long-term prognosis b/c the lesions in my organs are tiny. I start chemo on August 12. Can you pls share your chemo experiences with me? My Drs expect me to handle it very well b/c I'm only 27 years old. If you care to respond, pls post your age (if you don't mind, of course) b/c I have found that there are great differences in cancer behavior and success of treatment between women <35 and post menopausal women. Thank you so much!
Posts.Title: How did/do you feel during chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi, After failing 3 treatment regimens I'm now on Abraxane and desperately trying to get my mets under control. Has anyone taken this drug (it is very new -- just released 02.2005)? How is it working for you? Has anyone had a decrease in size or number of mets?
Posts.Title: Metastatic Breast Cancer -- anyone on Abraxane?

Posts.Content: Hello again yourspecialmiss, A biopsy is minor operation where the surgeon removes the lump (or part of it) and then sends a sample to the lab to see if the cells in the lump are actually cancerous. A lump can be many things from a cyst (fluid filled and non-cancerous) to fibrous (solid tissue, but still non-cancerous) to pre-cancer to cancer. One lump can also be composed of a combination of the above. Although I had 2 distinct tumors, I also had tiny bits of cancer throughout the breast so I had my one breast removed (mastectomy). I had a plastic surgeon perform reconstructive surgery and now even in a bikini you can't tell I had the breast removed! I am the only person in my family to have any kind of cancer. Just make sure that your Dr is thorough and finds out for sure one way or another what that lump is. Saying, "it's probably nothing" isn't good enough. Whenever I hear a Dr say "probably" I interrupt them actually Ask for an ultrasound. This test is very easy to perform and will tell you if the lump is fluid filled or solid which is a good place to start. If it is solid, I think you should have a biopsy b/c there isn't any other way to know for sure if the cells are cancerous. In my experience, it was best to have the lump removed entirely and have the whole thing biopsied b/c part of my lump was non-cancerous and part of it was deadly. What if the surgeon only sampled the part that was benign? I don't mean to frighten you, I just want you to make sure that you're ok! No one looks out for us better than ourselves. I have found that especially at our age, people are much more likely to say, "it's probably nothing". I hope I don't sound like I'm down on Drs either, b/c the Drs that I ended up with saved my life. Unfortunately, I had to see some not-so-great Drs before I found them. If you don't mind, pls post back to let me know how you are.
Posts.Title: I have a lump in my breast: should I be worried?

Posts.Content: Hi, Not to scare you or anything, but get any lump you find checked by a doctor you trust. The doctor should immediately order a ultrasound to see if the lump is a cyst (fluid filled) or a potential problem (solid mass). Not all solid masses are malignant tumors, so if yours is solid, then you will need to have a biopsy. I had a doctor send me home after she told me my lump was a cyst (just by touch). I wasn't comfortable with that and I demanded an ultrasound. 6 weeks later, after my biopsy, I was diagnosed with stage II breast cancer. I really don't mean to scare you and I apologize if I have. I just think it is so important for patients to look out for themselves. I hope everything works out!!
Posts.Title: Found a lump last night- need some advice

Posts.Content: You should be concerned enough about it to get it checked, but try not to worry yourself sick about it. I was diagnosed with breast cancer when I was 25 (I'm 27 now). 2 Drs sent me home without ordering any tests because they said I was "too young" to have breast cancer. I didn't believe them and I finally found a great Dr who performed my biopsy and subsequent mastectomy. Make sure you get all your questions answered!
Posts.Title: I have a lump in my breast: should I be worried?

Posts.Content: Hi Anxiety27, Sorry to hear about your mom. An important thing is to find out what stage the cancer is in. I was diagnosed at 25 with stage I and it came back when I was 27 at stage IV (the most advanced stage -- it means that the cancer has spread to other organs). I'm 29 now, so obviously I've been living with this for 2 years. I have had chemo every other week for 2 years, but I'm living my life. I went through a stage when I was paralyzed by fear, but I forced myself to snap out of it. Fear keeps us from enjoying anything. I'm happy to answer any questions you might have. Best wishes, Kalie
Posts.Title: Living with cancer the second time around

Posts.Content: Thanks yourspecialmiss. Don't worry too much about your surgery -- it's very simple, quick, and almost painless. When I had my lump removed I didn't even get general anaesthesia, I was awake for the 30 minute procedure. Afterwards, I didn't sleep on my stomach for about a week, but I didn't even need narcotic pain killers. I just took some Advil. The needle biopsy is even less invasive, but remember the results may not be as accurate due to sampling. If the surgeon removes the entire lump, he can have all those cells checked by the pathologist. If he takes samples with the needle, he could grab part of the lump that is benign, or pre-cancerous, and not realize that 1mm to the right are invasive cancer cells. When is your procedure? I'll be thinking about you! dazedandconfused, you are also talking about the needle biopsy. Very little pain involved. I hope everything works out!
Posts.Title: I have a lump in my breast: should I be worried?

Posts.Content: Well, dazed, whether to take the whole lump or not is a decision to be made between you and your Dr. Ask him/her about the pros/cons of both procedures. I can only offer my experience to you, and when my lump was removed it was composed of 3 different types of cells: benign, pre-cancer, & invasive cancer. I was very glad to have that knowledge and I would not have had such complete knowledge if I had the core needle biopsy. As far as your family history goes, it's good that you don't have a legacy of breast cancer in your family. But, only 10% of women who are diagnosed with breast cancer do have a family history. That means the other 90% (like me) go home thinking, "How did this happen. It doesn't make sense." Good idea to follow up with the Dr's office. If they don't call you, you must call them!
Posts.Title: I have a lump in my breast: should I be worried?

Posts.Content: Hi Anxiety27, Sorry to hear about your mom. An important thing is to find out what stage the cancer is in. I was diagnosed at 25 with stage I and it came back when I was 27 at stage IV (the most advanced stage -- it means that the cancer has spread to other organs). I'm 29 now, so obviously I've been living with this for 2 years. I have had chemo every other week for 2 years, but I'm living my life. I went through a stage when I was paralyzed by fear, but I forced myself to snap out of it. Fear keeps us from enjoying anything. I'm happy to answer any questions you might have. Best wishes, Kalie
Posts.Title: Living with cancer the second time around

Posts.Content: Lumps are not always felt. They may be too far below the surface, too small, etc. There are many different opinions on cancer treatment, but I can tell you this -- thousands and thousands of women die every year from breast cancer because it wasn't detected early enough. Mammograms are proven to save lives. Please encourage all the women you know to have annual mammograms. Ultrasound and MRI are also great diagnostic tools.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Question

Posts.Content: Hi there! I definitely agree that you should talk to your surgeon about it. Ask him for another ultrasound. Patients have to look out for themselves -- it's too easy to fall between the cracks in the medical system.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Question

Posts.Content: kaitkris, I'm so sorry you have to go through this. Treatment is long and tiring, but while your going though it try and remember that you're not alone and that millions of women (and men) have survived -- so will you! I wish I could post my email address for you. If you need to talk to someone who's had similar a similar experience just post to me on this board. ((Hug))
Posts.Title: Awating breast biopsy results

Posts.Content: orthogenic, What is the drug they are giving to your mother? How long has she been taking the drug? I too have mets in my lungs, liver and bone and we have not been able to shrink them.
Posts.Title: Living with cancer the second time around

Posts.Content: No, my past chemos were A/C and Navelbine, and I also participated in a phase I clinical trial for a kinase-inhibitor. What makes you say the Xeloda isn't working for your mom? Have her CT scans shown mixed response or no response? If so, insist her Drs switch her as soon as possible!! I've been fighting this thing for 3 years now (I'm 28) and if there's one thing I've learned it's that I have to be in control of my treatment b/c no Dr will ever look out for my life as well as I do. Sometimes the Drs want "to give it a few more wks" -- if I did that every time they suggested it I probably wouldn't be typing right now. What stage is your mom (if you don't mind me asking of course)? Is she estrogen and/or progesterone positive? HER-2 positive? Best wishes to you both.
Posts.Title: Metastatic Breast Cancer -- anyone on Abraxane?

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm 26 and a breast cancer survivor. I was diagnosed at 25. As part of my follow up treatment I'm taking Tamoxifen and Viadur (which is like Lupron). I had no side effects from the Tamoxifen, but I think I'm having some lousy ones from the Viadur: hot flashes (which are pretty common), nausea and back pain. Has anyone else experienced back pain? I couldn't find this listed as a side effect anywhere. Does the nausea ever go away? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Viadur/Lupron Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi there, Don't be afraid to call your Dr back and ask more questions. In my experience (I'm a 26yo breast cancer survivor) staining is simply part of the biopsy process. She probably freaked you out a bit with the word "specialized". The waiting is so hard. Of course you have a chance that the result will be negative -- a reeeally great chance!!
Posts.Title: Awating breast biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi fariegoddess, Hopefully this whole thing will turn out to be nothing. I would definitely recommend requesting an ultrasound. It is more difficult for a mgram to detect breast cancer in younger women b/c our breast tissue is denser. I found my lump by accident one day. It didn't hurt, it was kind of close to the surface so I could poke at it pretty easily. It was kind of mobile in that if I pushed it with my finger I could kind of move it around. It was irregularly shaped. I learned later that as cancer advances tumors become less and less mobile as they anchor themselves into surrounding tissue. I had some really great experiences with Drs, and I also had some experiences that made me question how these people graduated med school! My obgyn didn't want to send me for any tests at all. She said I was too young to have cancer. I wouldn't leave her office until she wrote me a script for an ultrasound. She isn't my obgyn anymore I also had a second tumor that one Dr missed. This Dr's ultrasound tech didn't pick it up, but another Dr's tech did. If your tests show that the lump is solid (not a cyst) you will probably need a biopsy, which really isn't too bad. If you need a biopsy (which I hope you don't btw) talk to your surgeon about performing a lumpectomy instead of a core needle biopsy. I wanted a core needle procedure which is less invasive, but my surgeon pointed out that if he used the needle to grab a sample, that sample is not necessarily indicative of the composition of the whole tumor. He was right -- my tumor was part DCIS (pre-cancer), part moderately aggressive cancer, and part very aggressive cancer cells. What if I continued treatment thinking I only had pre-cancer? I hope I'm not scaring you or getting ahead of the situation by talking about biopsies and stuff, it's just that you never know if people will revisit this board and I just really wanted to let you know about some potential problems that good Drs can help you avoid. I'll be thinking about you! If you think of anything else, post back! Also, pls post your results if you don't mind -- I hope everything turns out great! Kalie
Posts.Title: lump in left breast

Posts.Content: Most lumpectomies don't require a drain. Drains are reserved for more radical surgeries like mastectomies in which the body has lots of fluid that needs to drain over day/wks.
Posts.Title: lumpectomy with radiation

Posts.Content: Hello again everyone! Thanks for your interest. My story goes like this...I was 25 (2 yrs ago) and my wedding was in 3 wks. My fiance (husband now) and I were going to bed and when he hugged me goodnight, his thumb touched something hard on the outside of my left breast. Long story short...that happened in May, I couldn't get an appt with a Dr until the end of July b/c they all told me I was too young to have breast cancer and it was probably nothing. The Dr who I saw in July is absolutely fabulous -- I can't say enough about him. He took me very seriously from the start. He performed my lumpectomy, diagnosed my cancer, and told me I needed a mastectomy. Ah! What? At 25? That was the first time I actually cried. Naturally, my husband and I went for a second opinion. The second surgeon told me that even though my first ultrasound showed 2 masses, that the one she did after my lumpectomy didn't show the remaining lump. She actually started clapping! Then she recommended some radiation and sent us on our way. On the way to the car we decided to go back to the Dr who performed the lumpectomy. It's a good thing we did, b/c the second tumor was still inside my breast and was even more aggressive than the one that came out. Also, the MRI showed that residual cancer was throughout the breast and his first recommendation was the best one -- the breast had to go. So, my Dr performed a skin-conserving mastectomy with the aid of my plastic surgeon (who I also adore!). My fabulous husband was with me the whole time as I drooled in a morphine-induced sleep in recovery. I went through 3.5 months of tissue expansion to get the pectoralis and skin ready for the permanent implant and then I had surgery again and got my wonderful new silicone breast! Even in a bikini no one can tell I had a mastectomy -- without a bra or bikini top you can easily tell, but that's ok with me. I'm in full remission, coming up on the second anniversary of my diagnosis. I'm so thankful to my husband, my family and my Drs. Hehe, kind of makes me tear a bit thinking about all of them. I hope I didn't ramble too long! I hang around on this board b/c I know that there are other women out there who are unsure of what to do when they find a lump, or worse, who go to a medical professional and go home unsatisfied and scared. Thanks for listening!
Posts.Title: Is a Mammogram Mandatory to get a Biopsy??

Posts.Content: Hi there, Although the lump may be nothing it is extremely important that you go to a Dr. I found a lump in my left breast 2 months after my 25th birthday (last yr). It turned out to be Stage II breast cancer. I am fine now, but if I listened to everyone who told me it was nothing, I don't think I would be.
Posts.Title: lump in left breast

Posts.Content: No, it is not required by law to have a mammogram in order to have a biopsy, however, the Dr will want to prove that invasive techniques are necessary before putting the patient through the ordeal. Here's the other problem, the surgeon needs to know where the mass is before operating -- if the diagnostic technologies can't find it, and the surgeon can't feel it, he isn't going to be digging around with a scalpel in the breast tissue. What about another ultrasound at a different hospital? I was diagnosed with breast cancer at 25 (I'm 27 now), never had a mammogram, and the ultrasound tech found both my tumors. On my second ulatrasound, a different tech missed one of the tumors and said I only had one. My point is that people are fallible. The good news is that you said the lump hasn't changed. Cancer changes: it grows, the mass changes shape, it begins to adhere more firmly to the breast tissue so it isn't as movable, etc. I don't blame you for wanting it checked out. Get a prescription for an ultrasound from another Dr.
Posts.Title: Is a Mammogram Mandatory to get a Biopsy??

Posts.Content: Ralinda, I don't mean to frighten you, but breast puckering is a sign of cancer. You are willing to take your Dr's word without any sort of scan like an ultrasound or MRI? If I had done that I would be dead by now -- I'm only 28. Get a scan! -Kalie
Posts.Title: Breast puckering?

Posts.Content: Hi Hilery, I was diagnosed with breast cancer last year (at 25 yo) and my lump was hard, but it was still pretty movable. As tumors grow, they get less and less movable, but in the beginning you might be able to push them around. Usually, breast tumors aren't painful, so you have both the texture and the fact that it's painful leaning toward a negative test result! I hope everything turns out well!
Posts.Title: Breast lump

Posts.Content: Hi dj, I'm a 26 yo breast cancer survivor -- my lump didn't hurt at all. There are a lot of factors that go into symptoms like location and size of the lump. When did you notice it? Has it changed in size recently?
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, Last summer I had a mastectomy with reconstruction due to breast cancer. My implant is silicone (only approved for medical reasons now) and it has moved slightly out of place. I'm 26 and very active, so I think that my physical activity has contributed to this. I have already made an appt with my plastic surgeon, but I wanted to see if anyone else has had this experience. Anyone else have a breast implant slip out of place? How is this corrected? More surgery?
Posts.Title: Breast implant slipping out of place?

Posts.Content: Hi Dangergirl, How did your ultrasound turn out? Age is a factor in determining breast cancer risk, but it shouldn't be the only factor considered. I was diagnosed with stage II breast cancer at 25 (I'm 26 now). Always, always, always look out for yourself. If a doctor tells you not to worry about something and you still feel uncomfortable about it, go to another doctor. Demand another test. I hope I don't sound preachy. It's just that if I had listened to my first 2 doctors I probably wouldn't have been diagnosed until my cancer was in one of the late stages. I'm alive because I forced the Dr's to catch it early.
Posts.Title: scary- breast lump.. can you share your experience?

Posts.Content: It seems to me that your Dr has been quite thorough in running all the tests. My cancer was ductal carcinoma, so I can vouch that it can appear in the ducts, but that doesn't mean you have cancer. You could request an MRI to continue the non-invasive testing. My MRI showed every little speck of cancer in my breast. I'm not a Dr, but from my experience, it sounds like everything your Dr has suggested is reasonable. There doesn't seem to be any need to proceed with something as invasive as a biopsy just yet. As hard as it is, try not to worry about it, but keep on top of the testing. Make sure you go back in 6 months. I hope all is well!
Posts.Title: scary- breast lump.. can you share your experience?

Posts.Content: Hi nursekat, We are the same age -- it seems that you are having a similar experience to mine. I'm sorry to hear that. I had Dr's turn me away, refuse to do tests, etc. DEMAND an ultrasound. If your current Dr won't write the script for it, go see another one. If the ultrasound shows that the mass isn't fluid filled you should have another biopsy. As far as biopsies go, this is what I learned through my experience with cancer; a lump can be comprised of several different types of cells. Part of the lump may be benign, part precancer (DCIS), and part may be invasive cancer. Because of this, core needle biopsies, although less invasive, are less accurate. The needle may have sampled a part of the tumor that is benign while a mm to the right there are invasive cancer cells. Because of this potential issue my surgeon performed a lumpectomy and had my entire lump biopsied. Guess what? Mixture of DCIS and invasion! It's possible that I could have undergone less aggressive (and less effective) treatment b/c of flawed biopsy results with a core needle. Just because this is my experience doesn't mean you have cancer -- I hope I don't sound like the angle of death or anything! I just can't stress enough that we really need to look out for ourselves as patients. I think that young women have to be even more diligent due to Drs' tendencies to turn us away b/c we're "too young to have breast cancer". Although it's more unlikely, it's not impossible. Pursue it! Don't let anyone tell you everything is ok without proving it first. You'll feel so much better when you know for sure that you're ok!
Posts.Title: scary- breast lump.. can you share your experience?

Posts.Content: Hi there, I had my ribs and some spots in my back radiated for metastatic breast cancer and the only side-effect I had was some difficulty swallowing. I didn't even have skin abrasions. Best wishes, Kalie
Posts.Title: Radiation, what to expect

Posts.Content: I just completed a full cycle of A/C chemo which didn't really work for me. I have mets to both lungs, liver and the small of my back. The lesions in my lungs and back actually grew during the A/C round of chemo, so the Dr's are switching me to weekly doses of Navelbine. Does anyone have any experience with the side effects of this drug?
Posts.Title: Chemo: anyone have experience with Navelbine?

Posts.Content: Yes, but the results of those tests aren't very accurate b/c the cells behave very differently in a petri dish than in the body. I've been on Navelbine for 4 wks now and notice only a few side effects: soreness in right arm (injection arm), tingling in my fingertips sometimes. It does do a number on my white blood cell count though! Here's to 3 more doses!
Posts.Title: Chemo: anyone have experience with Navelbine?

Posts.Content: Just bumping this to the top. Anyone?
Posts.Title: Chemo: anyone have experience with Navelbine?

Posts.Content: Cysts are fluid-filled. It sounds like what you are dealing with is a solid mass, but this does not mean that it is a cancerous mass. Have you gotten your biopsy results yet? Wishing you the best, Kalie
Posts.Title: Fine Needle Aspiration

Posts.Content: Sometimes yes, sometimes no -- that's where the trouble comes in. I had a mastectomy 2 yrs ago not b/c I had 2 tumors in my left breast, but b/c: 1) my age -- 27. The likelihood of my cancer recurring sometime during my life was very high. (Since then it has returned.) 2) Besides the tumors, I had tiny spots of residual cancer throughout the breast so it was impossible to clear a safe margin and remove all the cancer. Choosing a mastectomy was the hardest decision of my life, but I made the right choice based on my particular diagnosis. If I had a tumor that was easily removed, with no lymph node involvement, and an easily cleared margin I don't think I would have gone with the mastectomy b/c I don't think I would have felt it was necessary. My advice is to get a few opinions and definitely ask for an MRI. MRIs show cancer that mammograms and ultrasounds do not. Best wishes to you. I know exactly what you're going through and it's tough -- so ****** tough...
Posts.Title: Is a mastectomy really necessary? What do you think?
